qas.question: German, English, and Afrikaans were the official languages until when in Namibia?
SWAPO thought Namibia should have what type of official language?
What is the primary language of Namibia, as SWAPO instituted?
There was a high rate of what due to monolingual instruction?
What is one of the 11 official languages of South Africa?
What percentage of people speak Afrikaans in Namibia?
What percentage of people speak German in Namibia?
The push for monolingual instruction has been a success in what African country?
How many people in Namibia can speak English at all?

context: Up to <a0_0>1990<a0_0/>, English, <b5_0>German<b5_0/> and Afrikaans were official languages. Long before <b8_0>Namibia<b8_0/>'s independence from South Africa, SWAPO was of the opinion that the country should become officially <a1_0>monolingual<a1_0/>, choosing this approach in contrast to that of its neighbour South Africa (which granted all 11 of its major languages official status), which was seen by them as "a deliberate policy of ethnolinguistic fragmentation." Consequently, SWAPO instituted <a2_0>English<a2_0/> as the sole official language of Namibia though only about <a3_0><b6_0><b7_0><b9_0>3%<b9_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/> of the population speaks it as a home language. Its implementation is focused on the civil service, education and the broadcasting system. Some other languages have received semi-official recognition by being allowed as medium of instruction in primary schools. It is expected of private schools to follow the same policy as state schools, and "English language" is a compulsory subject. As in other postcolonial African societies, the push for monolingual instruction and policy has resulted in a high rate of <a4_0>school drop-outs<a4_0/> and of individuals whose academic competence in any language is low.
